messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:30): notes in regards to a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4's <![dD][oO][cC][tT][yY][pP][eE]\s+[hH][tT][mM][lL]\s*> complaint that the HTML5 spec itself said (until quite recently) "1) A U+003C LESS-THAN SIGN (<) character. 2) A U+0021 EXCLAMATION MARK (!) character. 3) A U+0044 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER D or U+0064 LATIN SMALL LETTER D character. ..."

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:32): so at least the regexp is simpler than what the spec said (at least for people who understand regexps), which is admittedly a low bar but it's better than nothing :-)
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (17:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, the spec doesn't purport to be optimised for web developers, unlike the markup spec
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:45): a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4: It does purport to be intended for them (among others)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:45): ("This specification is intended for authors of documents and scripts that use the features defined in this specificaton ...")
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:46): wonders if a specificaton is kind of like a megaton
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:47): wonders if there exist specifications aren't intended for users of the specification
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:47): Hixie: I don't care enough to send email, so if you don't miss this in the log then s/specificaton/specification/ in #audience

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:49): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: How about e.g. http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-1/ which looks like it's intended for maybe tool authors and not for normal people?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:50): (and the user-friendly stuff is split into a separate document which is not part of the specification)

f19fe81cc92b1efcd1dd6a097ab17b05 (17:50): Hixie: I'm getting the unresponsive dialog script with Firefox 3.1/3.2 on the html5 spec. in status.js, findStatusByPosition the (high-low > 0) condition is never false.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:56): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Different use of 'uses' then
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:58): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I assume you meant to user the term 'users'?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:00): I had already rephrased the question in my head, but the sentence never reached my fingers
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:03): You should type with your nose instead
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:03): Much less distance for the nerve signals to travel
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:03): and correspondingly less chance of them getting lost in transit
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:05): I am slightly freaked out by the fact that I made a post to public-html on @summary and no one has replied within 24 hours.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:07): I am assuming that the reason was not that my arguments had a undeniable brilliance and so could not be refuted
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (18:07): html turns adult this year
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (18:07): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-talk/1991SepOct/0003.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): You can't really expect every post to get a reply - it's like a pyramid scheme, and someone has to get stuck at the leaf nodes
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: You can reply to multiple posts at the same time so preventing the exponential growth
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I take it you've never seen newsgroup threads?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): (I know pyramids don't have leaves but I don't know the term for the blocks you put at the very bottom of a pyramid :-( )
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:09): one sci.math thread is up past 1.5K messages
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): I would tend to assume that cornerstones are at corners
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:10): and pyramids only have four corners at the bottom
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:10): which is hardly exponential
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:10): it's a fractal pyramid :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:10): tries to visualise it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:10): fails
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:11): Sierpinski (sp?) Pyramid!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:11): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17: TimBL said at TPAC that it was 18 and a half then
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): http://philip.html5.org/demos/apng/sierpinski.png
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): Someone needs to make a 3D version of APNG
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: A3DPNG?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:12): is glad that the xml core wg seem to be opposed to normalization checking in xml
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (18:12): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I'm counting public mention, not inception
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:12): 0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17: hehe
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:13): I did feel rather inappropriate sitting beside timbl when he mentioned that in the HTML WG/TAG joint meeting at TPAC
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (18:13): bah, display doesn't like APNG
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:14): suggests that HTML might follow wizarding rules and come of age at 17 rather than muggle's rules of 18
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:14): suggests that HTML might follow Scottish law and come of age at 16
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:15): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: There's this neat image display tool called Firefox that might work better
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:15): tries to come up with a reason for it to be Scottish
